application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Effective methods for visualizing several sets of volumetric data simultaneously are presented which involve the composition of multiple volumetric rendering techniques. Although there are many methods for visualizing volumetric data, most of these methods can only render one set of volumetric data at a time. By rendering several volumetric data sets simultaneously, relationships among the data sets can be visualized, which may be difficult or impossible to visualize when the data sets are rendered individually.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: In some scientific applications, data are often sampled in a 3 0 volume. For example, geological data may be sampled at varying depths in arbitrarily located wells, oceanographic data may be measured at different depths and meteorological data may be measured at different altitudes near a storm. When data are sampled on a rectilinear grid, a set of volumetric data { ( z i , yj, z t , fi,j,k), where i , j , IC are indices of the grid} is generated. In other applications, data values fi are sampled at arbitrarily located points pi in 3 0 , thus a set of scattered data { ( p i , fi), i = 1 , . . . , N } is given. In this situation, an interpolation problem is commonly solved where a function F ( p ) which satisfies F ( p ; ) = f i for i = 1,. . . , N is constructed. Since the scattered data interpolation problem is not the main subject of this paper, the following references are given for further discussions: Barnhill [l], Foley & Lane [5], Franke [8] and Franke & Nielson[S]. After the function F ( p ) has been computed, the function is then usually evaluated over a rectilinear grid to generate a set of volumetric data for rendering. There are many visualization techniques for rendering volumetric data, however, most of these techniques can only display one set of volumetric data at a time. In this paper, we present visualization techniques which allow one to render several sets of volumetric data simultaneously.

We first discuss several techniques for visualizing volumetric data. These techniques include contour curves, color blended contour regions, projection graphs on surfaces, iso-value surface construction and hyper-surface projection graphs. We then use the composition of several of these display techniques to view multiple sets of volumetric data.

div.head: Volumetric Visualization
div.p: There have been many methods developed for volumetric visualization. In Drebin et al. [2], Levoy[l2], Montine[l4], Sabella [20] and Upson & Keeler [22], raycasting techniques are used to generate a volume rendering of the data. These methods are effective in that they produce realistic images of the given volumetric data and have helped scientists in many applications. However, most of these methods require a large amount of computation time and are not fully interactive, see Foley et al. [6] for some solutions to this problem. Furthermore, images generated by these methods are pixel-based, and the geometric topology of the volumetric data is not produced. In some applications, it may be crucial to be able to extract geometric topology from the given volumetric data. Many researchers have found it useful to display iso-surfaces of the volumetric data that have the same data value, an approach commonly known as contouring. In Lorensen & Cline[l3] and Wyvill et a1. [23], cube-based contouring methods are used to produce iso-value surfaces. In Payne & Toga[l8] and Foley & Lane [5], tetrahedra are used to construct iso-value surfaces instead of cubes. For further discussions on isGvalue surface construction, see Nielson & Ha.mann [l'i].

Many interactive techniques for volumetric visualization have been developed recently, such as those in Nielson & Hamann[l6]. In Kerlick [ll] and Speray & Kennon [21], geometric objects are used as probes that allow the user t o examine the given data values on the surface of the specified objects. This technique is very effective for examining regions of interest inside the volume and for observing any change of data values inside the volume.

The methods mentioned previously only represent a selected sample of the methods that have been developed for volumetric visualization. For more discussion on other methods, see Kaufman[lO]. Based on some the methods mentioned above, we next present methods that can be used to display several sets of volumetric data simultaneously.

div.head: Mult i-Volume Visualization
div.p: Suppose that several sets of volumetric data are given. For each set s, we denote the volumetric data set by { (zf , yj" , z; , f:,j,k), where i, j, IC are indices of the volume grid and ff,j,k is the data value at (XI, y;, z i ) } .

It is assumed that the given sets of data have the same bounding box; however, the data sets may be sampled using different grids. Suppose that a geometric object D, which is described by a set of vertices V and a set of triangles T, is also given. For example, D may be a plane, a sphere, an ellipsoid or a user-defined surface. In some applications, it may be more effective to use trimmed NURBS to represent the object D, see Rockwood et a1. [19] and Farin [3]. There can be several disjoint surfaces collectively called D. A restriction is that D be inside the bounding box of the given volumetric data. The object D will be used as a value probe that allows the user to examine the values of the volumetric data on the surface of the object. The position and size of D can also be interactively changed.

In the situation where D is a user-defined surface, such as a sphere, ellipsoid, plane or NURBS surface, D can be tessellated as fine as the user wants. In the following sections, we describe several visualization techniques which can be used to render the given volumetric data sets. An object D , which may consists of disjoint surfaces, is also assumed to be given. These techniques can be used simultaneously to render several sets of volumetric data at the same time.

div.head: Cl 5 F,(p) 5
div.p: Cl+1, then the color intensity I at the point p i s 4*(C1+1 -Fb(p))/(CI+l -Cl), where I( is the specified color intensity for the contour level Ci. For each triangle on D, if no contour curves intersect the triangle, then Gouraud shade the triangle using the computed color intensities at the three vertices of the triangle. If a contour curve intersects a triangle, then several types of intersection are possible. In general, the triangle is divided into more subtriangles based on the contour curve intersections. Each subtriangle is then rendered using Gouraud shading. For a detailed description on rendering color blended contours, see Foley et a1. [7] and Foley & Lane [5]. Using this visualization technique, any one of the given volumetric data sets may be rendered as color blended contours on D. It will be convenient to denote the operation of rendering color blended contours of a function S on a domain D by ColorBBlend( D, S).

div.head: Projected Surface Graph on D
div.p: A bivariate function F ( x , y) is often rendered as a surface graph by projecting a distance F ( z , y) perpendicularly from the point (z,y) in the planar domain.

When plotting a function F(p) defined over a 3 0 surface domain, a projected surface graph can also be constructed by projecting a distance proportional to F(p) from the point p on the surface D . This technique is described in detail in Foley et al. [7] for a spherical domain. In this section, the projected surface graph technique will be used to graph the values of a volumetric data set on some surface. Given points p on an object D and values Fd(p) of a volumetric data set s approximated at points p, a projected graph C(p) that represents Fb(p) can be defined as follows: c is the center of D . For convex objects, normal projection generally produce visually pleasing projected graph. However, if the object is non-convex and normal projection is used, then the projected graph G(p) may have self-intersection. If this occurs, then radial projection may be more effective. By rendering a set of volumetric data as a projected graph, the geometric information of the data can be visualized. Thus, any given volumetric data set s may be rendered as a projected graph defined on D . An effective approach is to render the projected graph as a transparent surface so that any information displayed on D is still visible. For example, using the technique described in the previous section, color blended contours of another data set may have already been rendered on D . The operac tor which renders the projected graph of the function S on a domain D is denoted by Proj-Graph(D, S).

div.head: Contour Curves on a Projected Surface Graph
div.p: The projected surface graph technique described in the previous section provides a way of visualizing data geometrically. More data may be visualized by displaying the data on the projected graph. For example, the color blended contours of some given data set may be computed and rendered on the projected graph. In this section we describe a simple, yet effective way of visualizing additional data on the projected graph using contour curves. There are several approaches for computing contour curves or iso-value curves, and a simple approach is as follows. Given a projected graph G(p) and values F,(p), the problem is to compute and plot contour curves of F,(p) on the graph G(p). Assume the triangle mesh that forms the projected graph is known. For each specified contour level Cl, every triangle in the mesh is checked to determine if a contour curve passes through it. If the data values of the triangle's three vertices are all greater or less than CI, then the contour curve for Ci does not pass through the triangle. If a contour curve passes through a triangle, then the intersections of the contour curve and the edges are computed. A detailed description for computing these contour curves is given in Foley & Lane [5]. The basic idea is that the computed contour curves can be plotted on the sur-

div.head: The Object D as an Isosurface
div.p: For some applications, it may be more effective to determine regions where a given data set is a t some specified value. Contouring a set of volumetric data will result in iso-value surfaces. The iso-value surface of a function S ( I , y, r ) corresponding to the value a is { ( t , y , r ) : S ( z , y , r ) = a } . We denote this set by IsoSurface(a, S ) . The computed isosurfaces then can be used to represent the object D, which then can be used to examine values of other volumetric data sets.

For example, one can compute iso-value surfaces using the first data set, then render color blended contours of another data set on the iso-value surfaces. When an iso-value surface is used as a probe, an additional step may need to be performed so that the surface normals to the projected graph can be approximated correctly. In a given surface, if all triangles are labelled in a counter clockwise or clockwise direction when viewed from the "outside", then the surface has a consistent triangle labelling. A consistent labelling of triangles is needed t o approximate outward surface normals at the vertices of a surface. Since some iso-value surface generation algorithms do not always produce surfaces with consistent triangle labelling, the triangles need to be re-labelled so that they are consistent. We now give an algorithm for labelling triangles in a mesh such that they are consistent. The algorithm assumes that the inter-connection topology of the triangles in the mesh is given, i.e. which triangles are neighbors. However, most iso-value surface construction algorithms do not generate the inter-connection topology of the isGvalue surfaces; therefore, it is assumed that the topology information have been computed before using the following algorithm. In the above algorithm, the Exchange(a,b) procedure exchanges the contents in a and b. The procedure Consistent(tri-1, t r i 2 ) returns TRUE if tri-1 and tri-2, which are neighbors to ea.ch ot,her, are hbelled consistently.

The algorithm in Lorensen & Cline[l3] was used for constructing iso-value surfaces. There is an ambiguity problem in their algorithm which may result in holes in the iso-value surfaces, see Wyvill We implemented the algorithm in [13] with the efficiency enhancement stated at the end of their paper. The iso-value surface construction is performed on a slice by slice basis instead of voxel by voxel basis and the previous slice's information is stored so that each vertex is computed once only. This reduces the number of vertices and triangles in the iso-value surfaces and it provides the inter-connection topology, thus the re-label algorithm above can be applied easily. .

div.head: Hyper-Surface Projection Graph
div.p: In Section 3.2, the projected surface graph technique uses either a normal or radial projection, however, another type of projection may also be used. The 4 0 hyper-surface for the function F ( z , y , z ) on a domain D is the set of points ( z , y , z , F ( z , y , z ) ) ,

where (z,y,z) E D. Three different parallel projections to 3-space are (z,y,F(z, y,z)), (2, F ( t , y , z ) , z ) and ( F ( z , y, z ) , y, 2). These correspond to projecting parallel to the z , y and 2 axes, respectively; and each projection yields a 3 0 surface, see Nielson et a1. [15] for additional examples on other domains. Using this hyper-surface projection technique, additional sets of volumetric data may be rendered. For example, three data sets may be represented by hyper-surface graphs, which are computed by projecting parallel to the t, y and z axes. One may also render even more data sets by using the projected surface graph technique described in Section 3.2 to project surfaces from the hyper-surface graphs. However, it is unlikely that one could effectively visualize these additional data sets.
The hyper-surface projection graph of the function S on the domain D is denoted by HyperSurf(D, S).

div.head: Examples
div.p: We now use different combinations of the visualization techniques described in the previous sections to render several sets of volumetric data simultaneously. Three sets of volumetric data were generated using the test functions below:

brevity, we will refer to the data sets computed u s ing the above test functions as S1, S2 and S3. These data sets are bounded by the volume [0,l]x [0,l]x [0,l] and are evaluated at a 5 0 x 5 0~5 0 volume grid. Using mineral samples near Roosevelt Lake in Arizona, a set of volumetric data was generated that represents lead samples. We will refer to this data set by S4. The volume of the data set S4 has been scaled so that it has the same volume size as data sets S1, S2 and S3.

In Figure 1, the plane z = 0.2 is used as the object D . In this figure three visualization techniques are used to render the data sets S2, S3 and S1. Using the operator notation introduced in the previous sections, we can denote the composition of the techniques shown in Figure 1 by
div.formula: Fig 1 = Color-Blend(D, S2) + Proj-Graph(D, S3) + Cont-Curve(D, S1, Proj_Graph(D,S3)),
div.p: where D is the plane t = 0.2. The color bar shown in the bottom of the figure depicts the colors used for the color blended contours and the contour curves on the parabola. The values of the contour levels used for each given data set are shown under the color bar. Figure 2 uses S4, S2 and S1 as the three volumetric data sets, and the data are visualized using two objects as D, a sphere and an ellipsoid. Using the operator notation, Figure 2 depicts Thus far, we have used the color blended contours to represent the first data set, the projected graph to represent the second data set and the contour curves to represent the third data set; however, the user is allowed to interactively select which graphics representation to use for a particular data set. For example, the user may want to use the color blended contours to visualize the third data set instead of the first data set.

Figures 3 and 4 depict how to visualize four sets of volumetric data. The Re-label-Triangleso procedure given in Section 3.4 was used to re-label the triangles in the iso-value surfaces shown in the figures. In Figure 3, the iso-value surface represents regions where the data set S1 is 0.4, which can be denoted by IsoSurface(0.4,Sl). The iso-value surface is used as where D = Iso-Surface(0.4, SI). In Figure 4, the iso-value surface represented by IsoSurface ( 0.4, S2) is used as the object D and the composite techniques shown can be denoted by
div.formula: Fig 4 = Color,Blend(D, S4) + Proj-Graph(D, S3) + Cont,Curve(D, S1, Proj-Graph(D, S3)),
div.p: where D = Iso-Surface(0.4, S2).
In Figures 5 and 6, the hyper-surface projection graph technique is added to Figures 3 and 4, where D = Iso-Surface(0.4, S2).

div.head: Concluding Remarks
div.p: Using different combinations of the techniques described in this paper, one can visualize multiple sets of volumetric data simultaneously. Each of these techniques has its advantages and disadvantages. For example, the color blended contour regions are effective on the rapidly varying lead data (S4). However, the projection graphs of rapidly varying data are sometimes difficult t o visualized.

The following steps summarize the compositional techniques that can be used to visualize multiple sets of volumetric data. It should be noted that F8(p) can be the same or different in each of the following steps.

Generate an object D which will be used as a value probe. The object may be a collection of userdefined surfaces or iw-value surfaces generated by some iso-value surface construction algorithm applied to some function F,(p) F,(p), where s is a specified data set, then render the color blended contours on D.

Compute a projected graph defined on D using values F8(p) of a specified data set, then shade the projected graph as a transparent surface. Compute and plot contour curves on the projected graph using the values Fd(p) of some specified data set s. Using another data set, compute and plot hypersurface projection graphs.

The data sets used in the above steps are specified by the user. For example, the user may want to render color blended contours and a projected graph of the same data set, while the contour curves on the projected graph may represent a different data set. Using these methods, several different data sets may be visualized simultaneously.

During the refereeing process, the authors became aware of related work recently published by Ferguson & Winget [4]. They present several effective visualization techniques and apply them t o finite-element analysis. Their isosurface sampling method is used t o visualize contours of one data set sampled and displayed on the isosurface of another data set.

We have presented several techniques for visualizing multiple sets of volumetric data. Using these techniques for rendering several sets of volumetric data simultaneously can help scientists visualize the relationships among the data sets, which may be difficult or impossible to visualize when the data sets are rendered individually.

The basic approach for computing and rendering color blended contours on the object D is as follows. First compute contour curves of the specified contour levels Cl. For each point p on D , a color intensity is computed based on the value Fb(p) at the point p . If

face of the graph G ( p ) . Note that the values F,(p) used in this section do not have to be computed using the same data set that was used to compute the projected graph G(p). Thus, the projected graph may represent a data set and the contour curves may represent a different data set. The operator which plots the contour curves of a function S evaluated over a domain D and plotted on a projected graph P is denoted by Cont-Curve(D,S,P), where P = Proj-Graph(D,S). Plotting the contour curves of S on the domain D is then denoted by Cont-Curve(D,S,D).

Procedure R.&bel-Triangleso re-labels triangles in the given mesh such that they are labelled consistently (clockwise or counter clockwise). The procedure assumes that the given triangle mesh is contiguous, i.e. there are no disjoint triangles in the mesh. In our implementation, we allow the user to interactively change the position and the size of the objects D . When an object's position or size is changed, new color blended contours, projected graph and contour curves are computed and rendered.

ear interpolant. Let where Bo(t) = 1-t, B l ( t ) = t , 3: = (z-~i)/(z~+~-z~),
and {f:,j,k,. . . , fid+l,j+l,k+l} are the data values at the
eight corners of the subgrid. The key is that for each
data set s, F8(p) will be evaluated and displayed for
points p on the object D. If the volumetric data are
given on a fine regular mesh, then trilinear interpola-
tion is a reasonable approximation for most data sets.
If the regular mesh is course or if the scalar values vary
rapidly from cell to cell, then higher-order approxima-
tions can be used to evaluate Fb(p) inside each cell,
such as tricubic tensor product methods.
If the
volumetric data varies rapidly or if the surface domain
D has high curvature, then D can be decomposed into
a 1a.rger number of smaller triangles.
In order to examine the values of the given volu-
metric data on the surface of the object D, the values
need to be approximated first. Let F,(p) be the ap-
proximated value of the volumetric data set s at a
point p on D. The value F,(p) can be computed by
first determining the subgrid in which the point p lies
in, then perform a simple trilinear interpolation using
the data values at the eight corners of the subgrid. The

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: The images shown in this paper were generated on a Silicon Graphics Iris 4D/340 VGX workstation. We wish to thank Wayne Woodland for his fine photography. We also thank the reviewers for their helpful comments. This work was supported by the U.S.
